case_vignette: A 66-year-old female with past medical history of right breast cancer treated with radiation presents with a slowly growing mass on the right breast. She states the spot initially began as a small bruise then progressively enlargened over the past few months and now spontaneously bleeds. Examination reveals a violaceous, red exophytic thick nodule on the right breast. An excisional biopsy reveals atypical pleomorphic endothelial cells lining ill-defined vascular spaces and prominent hemorrhage.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

trial_0.vignette_frq: Angiosarcoma of the breast associated with radiation therapy.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a slowly growing mass on my right breast that started as a small bruise and has enlarged over the past few months. It now bleeds on its own.
Have you noticed any changes in the skin over the mass, such as puckering or dimpling?
No, there is no puckering or dimpling, but the skin over the mass has turned into a purplish-red, bumpy growth.
Do you have any personal or family history of breast cancer or other cancers?
Yes, I have a personal history of breast cancer.
Final Diagnosis: Recurrent breast cancer.
